title: Bilateral Sensorineural Hearing Loss Post-Airbag Deployment
chief_complaint: I've noticed decreased hearing in both ears for about 4 to 6 months, ever since the air bags went off in my car accident. I also have constant, bothersome ringing and a feeling of pressure in my ears.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset 4-6 months ago following acoustic trauma (airbag deployment).
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral; patient perceives left ear as poorer.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant difficulty recognizing speech (very poor WRS).
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation and management of hearing loss and tinnitus.

history.present_illness: Patient was involved in a car accident 4-6 months prior with airbag deployment. Reports bilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural pressure since the event. A CT scan was performed and results were normal.
history.otologic_history: No other reported otologic symptoms or history aside from the accident.
history.noise_exposure_history: Acute acoustic trauma from airbag deployment.
history.prior_management: Had a hearing test prior to the accident used for comparison (showed significantly better scores previously).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal to slight SNHL (250-1000 Hz) sloping to moderate-severe SNHL (1500-8000 Hz). Left ear: Normal (250-500 Hz) sloping to mild-to-moderately severe SNHL (750-8000 Hz). Symmetrical configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs are in agreement with PTAs (mild loss). Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are very poor bilaterally, showing a significant decrease compared to pre-accident records (approx 50% drop Left, 70% drop Right).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows hypercompliant tympanic membrane (Type Ad). Left ear shows normal tympanogram (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right: Normal thresholds 500-2000 Hz, absent at 4000 Hz. Left: Normal ipsi/contra 500-4000 Hz (except contra absent at 4000 Hz). Reflex decay negative at 500 and 1000 Hz.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral, sloping, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. While pure-tone thresholds indicate mild-to-severe loss, speech discrimination is disproportionately poor (36-42%), significantly reduced from pre-accident levels. Tympanometry indicates a hypercompliant system on the right and normal mobility on the left.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is likely a result of the acoustic trauma from the airbag deployment.
While we can amplify sound, your ability to understand speech (clarity) has been significantly affected, meaning making things louder may not make them perfectly clear.
We should discuss hearing aids to help with volume and tinnitus management, but given the poor speech clarity, we may also need to consider if a cochlear implant evaluation is appropriate.
Hearing protection is recommended in noisy environments to prevent further damage.
notes_for_actor: You are likely frustrated because you had better hearing before the car accident 4-6 months ago.
Emphasize the constant ringing (tinnitus) and the feeling of pressure in your ears.
You perceive the left ear as worse, even though the test results show they are fairly similar in severity.
